data.author: Serif
data.content: Thanks for the summaries. Getting sued in business is an occupational hazard and none of these allegations seem to have been upheld. Often better to settle out of court when you can - even if it means swallowing your pride and you think the other party are just trying it on - you save more on legal fees than the cost of any settlement payment and don’t have to waste endless time on legal proceedings when you should be focusing on your business.

data.author: Early_Bird
data.content: Summary Publicly documented litigation involving Marc Bruner in the oil and gas sector centers mainly on an investment and corporate governance dispute, not a finding of wrongdoing. Key Case: Nation SLP, LLC v. Bruner (Colorado, 2022) This case involved a dispute among oil and gas investors and company managers connected to Australian exploration projects. Bruner, alleged to be Chair and CEO of Paltar Petroleum, was accused (along with others) of manipulating corporate control to exclude investors from profits. Procedural Focus, Not Liability An earlier federal lawsuit (2017) alleging fraud and racketeering was dismissed on forum non conveniens grounds because related litigation was underway in Australia. In 2022, the Colorado Court of Appeals ruled that this dismissal did not bar the case from proceeding in Colorado, since it was not a decision on the merits. The case was reversed and remanded for further proceedings. No Substantive Finding Against Bruner The appellate decision addressed where the case could be heard, not whether Bruner was liable. Other Related Litigation In Brody v. Bruner (Tenth Circuit), Bruner appeared in connection with PetroHunter, an energy company, in a bankruptcy-related dispute. The court affirmed dismissal of civil conspiracy claims. Bottom line: Bruner has been involved in oil and gas–related litigation primarily over investment control and corporate governance, with rulings focused on procedural issues, not determinations of fraud or liability.

data.author: Early_Bird
data.content: Paygrove, have you heard of ChatGPT? a very useful tool this day and age and will answer all the questions you're posting on here. Its good that you're probing though... going deeper in your research than most punters that just chase noise Alright, oil & gas resources 101—this is a good question and one a lot of people mix up. ### What are **2C Contingent Resources**? **2C** is the *best estimate* (or “most likely”) volume within **Contingent Resources** under the PRMS (Petroleum Resources Management System). Contingent Resources are: * **Discovered** hydrocarbons (there’s been a well, test, or solid evidence) * **Not yet commercial** because of *contingencies* like: * No development plan yet * Economics not approved * Regulatory or fiscal uncertainty * Missing infrastructure * Pending technology or market access Think of **2C** as: > “We know the hydrocarbons are there, and this is our most realistic volume — we just haven’t cleared all the business or technical hurdles yet.” --- ### What are **Prospective Resources**? Prospective Resources are: * **Undiscovered** * Based on geological interpretation, seismic, and analogs * Dependent on: * A future discovery * Development feasibility * Commercial approval In plain terms: > “We *think* hydrocarbons might be there, but we haven’t drilled and proven it.” They’re typically expressed with: * **Low / Best / High estimates** * **Chance of Discovery (Pg)** --- ### Why **2C is better than Prospective** “Better” here means **lower risk and higher confidence**. | Aspect              | 2C Contingent            | Prospective             | | ------------------- | ------------------------ | ----------------------- | | Discovery status    | ✅ Discovered             | ❌ Undiscovered          | | Geological risk     | Low                      | High                    | | Data quality        | Wells + tests + seismic  | Mostly seismic + models | | Key risk            | Commercial / development | Geological + commercial | | Closer to reserves? | ✅ Yes                    | ❌ Much earlier          | | Typical value       | Higher                   | Lower                   | So: * **2C has already cleared geological risk** * **Prospective still has to prove hydrocarbons even exist** That’s why investors, lenders, and partners usually: * Discount **Prospective Resources heavily** * Take **2C much more seriously**, especially if contingencies are clear and solvable --- ### Simple analogy * **Prospective**: *“There might be gold in that mountain.”* * **2C Contingent**: *“We’ve found gold, measured it, but we haven’t built the mine yet.”*

data.author: Serif
data.content: Thanks for the summaries. Getting sued in business is an occupational hazard and none of these allegations seem to have been upheld. Often better to settle out of court when you can - even if it means swallowing your pride and you think the other party are just trying it on - you save more on legal fees than the cost of any settlement payment and don’t have to waste endless time on legal proceedings when you should be focusing on your business.

data.author: Early_Bird
data.content: Summary Publicly documented litigation involving Marc Bruner in the oil and gas sector centers mainly on an investment and corporate governance dispute, not a finding of wrongdoing. Key Case: Nation SLP, LLC v. Bruner (Colorado, 2022) This case involved a dispute among oil and gas investors and company managers connected to Australian exploration projects. Bruner, alleged to be Chair and CEO of Paltar Petroleum, was accused (along with others) of manipulating corporate control to exclude investors from profits. Procedural Focus, Not Liability An earlier federal lawsuit (2017) alleging fraud and racketeering was dismissed on forum non conveniens grounds because related litigation was underway in Australia. In 2022, the Colorado Court of Appeals ruled that this dismissal did not bar the case from proceeding in Colorado, since it was not a decision on the merits. The case was reversed and remanded for further proceedings. No Substantive Finding Against Bruner The appellate decision addressed where the case could be heard, not whether Bruner was liable. Other Related Litigation In Brody v. Bruner (Tenth Circuit), Bruner appeared in connection with PetroHunter, an energy company, in a bankruptcy-related dispute. The court affirmed dismissal of civil conspiracy claims. Bottom line: Bruner has been involved in oil and gas–related litigation primarily over investment control and corporate governance, with rulings focused on procedural issues, not determinations of fraud or liability.

data.author: DerekLondon
data.content: Courtesy of AI Here’s what’s publicly documented about lawsuits related to oil and gas involving Marc Bruner (sometimes spelled Bruner in filings) — particularly civil litigation tied to investment and corporate disputes in the oil sector: 🛢️ 1. Nation SLP, LLC v. Bruner — Oil & Gas Investment Dispute (Colorado) This is the key case involving oil and gas business litigation where Marc Bruner was a defendant: Case Overview Name: Nation SLP, LLC v. Bruner Court: Colorado Court of Appeals (Colorado, USA) Decision: July 14, 2022 Defendants: Marc Bruner and Michael Caetano Plaintiff: Nation SLP, LLC Core Issue: Dispute among oil and gas investors and company managers about control of profits and corporate governance in Australian oil and gas exploration entities. � Colorado Lawyer +1 Background The dispute stemmed from investors and related companies formed around exploration permits for oil and gas properties in Australia. Investors created entities like Nation SLP, Paltar Petroleum, and Nation Energy to fund and operate projects. � law.justia.com Bruner was alleged to have served as Chair and CEO of Paltar Petroleum, with Caetano holding key executive roles in Nation Energy and Nation Australia. The plaintiffs claimed that Bruner and Caetano manipulated boards and company decisions to cut investors out of their share of profits from the exploration projects. � law.justia.com Lawsuit History Earlier Federal Case (2017): Plaintiffs filed a suit in U.S. District Court (Colorado) alleging fraud, racketeering, and breaches of fiduciary duty involving Bruner and others. That case was dismissed on forum non conveniens grounds because related litigation was pending in Australia, and Australian law governed many claims. � law.justia.com Colorado Court of Appeals (2022): In Nation SLP, LLC v. Bruner, the Colorado appeals court held that the earlier dismissal for forum non conveniens did not bar the present Colorado lawsuit under “res judicata” (claim preclusion) because dismissals on those grounds are not judgments on the merits. The case was reversed and remanded for further proceedings in Colorado. � law.justia.com 📌 Key point: This lawsuit involves Bruner in the context of oil and gas investment and corporate control disputes, but it was not a verdict or finding of liability against him — rather, it focused on procedural issues about where the case could properly be heard. � law.justia.com 🧾 Additional Litigation Not Directly About Oil, But Related to Bruner in Energy Context Brody v. Bruner — Bankruptcy & PetroHunter (Energy Sector) There is a Brody v. Bruner case in the U.S. Tenth Circuit involving Marc A. Bruner in the broader energy space (specifically petroleum/energy company PetroHunter and bankruptcy issues). That appeal affirmed the dismissal of civil conspiracy claims related to PetroHunter’s bankruptcy, where Bruner was described as an oil and gas developer and founder of r

data.author: Early_Bird
data.content: Courtesy of AI: 🔹 Who Marc A. Bruner Is Marc A. Bruner is a veteran American oil and gas executive and entrepreneur with a multi-decade career in founding, leading, and scaling energy companies. He was recently appointed Strategic Investment Advisor to Upland Resources, bringing industry experience and aligning interests with Upland shareholders via an indirect equity stake (about 6 % through his company Lost Soldier Oil & Gas). 🛢️ Career Highlights and Track Record: Marc Bruner has a long history in oil and gas, including: 🔸 Ultra Petroleum Corporation Bruner was the founding Chairman of Ultra Petroleum, a company that grew significantly under his leadership, achieving a market capitalization above US $7 billion. 🔸 Pennaco Energy Inc. He founded Pennaco, focused on coalbed methane development, and saw it sold to Marathon Oil for about US $550 million. 🔸 Falcon Oil & Gas Ltd. Bruner founded and led Falcon, which grew to a valuation above US $3.7 billion during his tenure. 🔸 Lost Soldier Oil & Gas LLC He is CEO and founder of Lost Soldier, an energy company best known for a major natural gas discovery in the U.S. (about 6 trillion cubic feet). That discovery is also an asset where Upland has exposure via strategic partnership structures. 🔸 Other Leadership Roles and Projects Across more than 50 years in the energy sector, Bruner has held executive roles in multiple companies (including earlier roles at Mako Energy, Nation Energy, and others) and has been active as a board member, CEO, or chairman in various upstream and exploration firms. 📈 Reputation and Focus Bruner is known for: Building early-stage companies into significant players in their markets. Creating value through exploration and development rather than just financial engineering. Negotiating major contracts with large energy service and production firms. He’s regarded in energy circles as a serial founder/executive rather than a controversial figure tied to fraud or racketeering allegations. There are no credible reports linking him to such legal issues in major jurisdictions. 📌 In Context of Upland Resources Bruner’s role as Strategic Investment Advisor to Upland Resources reflects his track record in: Resource discovery and development Company building and exit strategy Capital allocation in exploration assets He also holds an indirect share in Upland, which aligns his interests with shareholders. 🧠 Bottom Line Marc Bruner is a well-known energy industry executive with fifty+ years of experience building exploration and development companies. His appointment at Upland is part of a strategic partnership via Lost Soldier and reflects his history of growing assets and companies — not involvement in criminal legal cases tied to fraud or racketeering.

data.author: Early_Bird
data.content: Upland (via Upland Big Oil) has submitted its application for an exclusive award of the PSC for Block SK334 to the Sarawak state government and PETROS (the state oil company/authority). They are actively awaiting approval — but it has not yet been granted. The Joint Technical Study (JTS) — a key prerequisite to a PSC award — was successfully completed and delivered to PETROS. That technically positions them well in the process. The last few RNSs show they've lined up financing to drill and Bruner is ready to get his teeth stuck in to UPL, so one would assume we are very close now to PSC being awarded

data.author: Early_Bird
data.content: With SK334 Upland have a 45% stake and are in JV with BOV who have the remaining 55%. Block SK334 itself does not yet have a granted petroleum licence or production sharing contract (PSC) from the Sarawak authorities — Upland and its partners are in the process of securing that licence/PSC with PETROS

data.author: Early_Bird
data.content: Paygrove, have you heard of ChatGPT? a very useful tool this day and age and will answer all the questions you're posting on here. Its good that you're probing though... going deeper in your research than most punters that just chase noise Alright, oil & gas resources 101—this is a good question and one a lot of people mix up. ### What are **2C Contingent Resources**? **2C** is the *best estimate* (or “most likely”) volume within **Contingent Resources** under the PRMS (Petroleum Resources Management System). Contingent Resources are: * **Discovered** hydrocarbons (there’s been a well, test, or solid evidence) * **Not yet commercial** because of *contingencies* like: * No development plan yet * Economics not approved * Regulatory or fiscal uncertainty * Missing infrastructure * Pending technology or market access Think of **2C** as: > “We know the hydrocarbons are there, and this is our most realistic volume — we just haven’t cleared all the business or technical hurdles yet.” --- ### What are **Prospective Resources**? Prospective Resources are: * **Undiscovered** * Based on geological interpretation, seismic, and analogs * Dependent on: * A future discovery * Development feasibility * Commercial approval In plain terms: > “We *think* hydrocarbons might be there, but we haven’t drilled and proven it.” They’re typically expressed with: * **Low / Best / High estimates** * **Chance of Discovery (Pg)** --- ### Why **2C is better than Prospective** “Better” here means **lower risk and higher confidence**. | Aspect              | 2C Contingent            | Prospective             | | ------------------- | ------------------------ | ----------------------- | | Discovery status    | ✅ Discovered             | ❌ Undiscovered          | | Geological risk     | Low                      | High                    | | Data quality        | Wells + tests + seismic  | Mostly seismic + models | | Key risk            | Commercial / development | Geological + commercial | | Closer to reserves? | ✅ Yes                    | ❌ Much earlier          | | Typical value       | Higher                   | Lower                   | So: * **2C has already cleared geological risk** * **Prospective still has to prove hydrocarbons even exist** That’s why investors, lenders, and partners usually: * Discount **Prospective Resources heavily** * Take **2C much more seriously**, especially if contingencies are clear and solvable --- ### Simple analogy * **Prospective**: *“There might be gold in that mountain.”* * **2C Contingent**: *“We’ve found gold, measured it, but we haven’t built the mine yet.”*

data.author: Serif
data.content: Thanks for the summaries. Getting sued in business is an occupational hazard and none of these allegations seem to have been upheld. Often better to settle out of court when you can - even if it means swallowing your pride and you think the other party are just trying it on - you save more on legal fees than the cost of any settlement payment and don’t have to waste endless time on legal proceedings when you should be focusing on your business.

data.author: Early_Bird
data.content: Summary Publicly documented litigation involving Marc Bruner in the oil and gas sector centers mainly on an investment and corporate governance dispute, not a finding of wrongdoing. Key Case: Nation SLP, LLC v. Bruner (Colorado, 2022) This case involved a dispute among oil and gas investors and company managers connected to Australian exploration projects. Bruner, alleged to be Chair and CEO of Paltar Petroleum, was accused (along with others) of manipulating corporate control to exclude investors from profits. Procedural Focus, Not Liability An earlier federal lawsuit (2017) alleging fraud and racketeering was dismissed on forum non conveniens grounds because related litigation was underway in Australia. In 2022, the Colorado Court of Appeals ruled that this dismissal did not bar the case from proceeding in Colorado, since it was not a decision on the merits. The case was reversed and remanded for further proceedings. No Substantive Finding Against Bruner The appellate decision addressed where the case could be heard, not whether Bruner was liable. Other Related Litigation In Brody v. Bruner (Tenth Circuit), Bruner appeared in connection with PetroHunter, an energy company, in a bankruptcy-related dispute. The court affirmed dismissal of civil conspiracy claims. Bottom line: Bruner has been involved in oil and gas–related litigation primarily over investment control and corporate governance, with rulings focused on procedural issues, not determinations of fraud or liability.

Bruner — Oil & Gas Investment Dispute (Colorado) This is the key case involving oil and gas business litigation where Marc Bruner was a defendant: Case Overview Name: Nation SLP, LLC v. Bruner Court: Colorado Court of Appeals (Colorado, USA) Decision: July 14, 2022 Defendants: Marc Bruner and Michael Caetano Plaintiff: Nation SLP, LLC Core Issue: Dispute among oil and gas investors and company managers about control of profits and corporate governance in Australian oil and gas exploration entities. � Colorado Lawyer +1 Background The dispute stemmed from investors and related companies formed around exploration permits for oil and gas properties in Australia. Investors created entities like Nation SLP, Paltar Petroleum, and Nation Energy to fund and operate projects. � law.justia.com Bruner was alleged to have served as Chair and CEO of Paltar Petroleum, with Caetano holding key executive roles in Nation Energy and Nation Australia. The plaintiffs claimed that Bruner and Caetano manipulated boards and company decisions to cut investors out of their share of profits from the exploration projects. � law.justia.com Lawsuit History Earlier Federal Case (2017): Plaintiffs filed a suit in U.S. District Court (Colorado) alleging fraud, racketeering, and breaches of fiduciary duty involving Bruner and others. That case was dismissed on forum non conveniens grounds because related litigation was pending in Australia, and Australian law governed many claims. � law.justia.com Colorado Court of Appeals (2022): In Nation SLP, LLC v. Bruner, the Colorado appeals court held that the earlier dismissal for forum non conveniens did not bar the present Colorado lawsuit under “res judicata” (claim preclusion) because dismissals on those grounds are not judgments on the merits. The case was reversed and remanded for further proceedings in Colorado. � law.justia.com 📌 Key point: This lawsuit involves Bruner in the context of oil and gas investment and corporate control disputes, but it was not a verdict or finding of liability against him — rather, it focused on procedural issues about where the case could properly be heard. � law.justia.com 🧾 Additional Litigation Not Directly About Oil, But Related to Bruner in Energy Context Brody v. Bruner — Bankruptcy & PetroHunter (Energy Sector) There is a Brody v. Bruner case in the U.S. Tenth Circuit involving Marc A. Bruner in the broader energy space (specifically petroleum/energy company PetroHunter and bankruptcy issues). data.content: Courtesy of AI: 🔹 Who Marc A. Bruner Is Marc A. Bruner is a veteran American oil and gas executive and entrepreneur with a multi-decade career in founding, leading, and scaling energy companies. He was recently appointed Strategic Investment Advisor to Upland Resources, bringing industry experience and aligning interests with Upland shareholders via an indirect equity stake (about 6 % through his company Lost Soldier Oil & Gas). 🛢️ Career Highlights and Track Record: Marc Bruner has a long history in oil and gas, including: 🔸 Ultra Petroleum Corporation Bruner was the founding Chairman of Ultra Petroleum, a company that grew significantly under his leadership, achieving a market capitalization above US $7 billion. 🔸 Pennaco Energy Inc. He founded Pennaco, focused on coalbed methane development, and saw it sold to Marathon Oil for about US $550 million. 🔸 Falcon Oil & Gas Ltd. Bruner founded and led Falcon, which grew to a valuation above US $3.7 billion during his tenure. 🔸 Lost Soldier Oil & Gas LLC He is CEO and founder of Lost Soldier, an energy company best known for a major natural gas discovery in the U.S. (about 6 trillion cubic feet). That discovery is also an asset where Upland has exposure via strategic partnership structures. 🔸 Other Leadership Roles and Projects Across more than 50 years in the energy sector, Bruner has held executive roles in multiple companies (including earlier roles at Mako Energy, Nation Energy, and others) and has been active as a board member, CEO, or chairman in various upstream and exploration firms. 📈 Reputation and Focus Bruner is known for: Building early-stage companies into significant players in their markets. Creating value through exploration and development rather than just financial engineering. Negotiating major contracts with large energy service and production firms. He’s regarded in energy circles as a serial founder/executive rather than a controversial figure tied to fraud or racketeering allegations. There are no credible reports linking him to such legal issues in major jurisdictions. 📌 In Context of Upland Resources Bruner’s role as Strategic Investment Advisor to Upland Resources reflects his track record in: Resource discovery and development Company building and exit strategy Capital allocation in exploration assets He also holds an indirect share in Upland, which aligns his interests with shareholders. 🧠 Bottom Line Marc Bruner is a well-known energy industry executive with fifty+ years of experience building exploration and development companies. His appointment at Upland is part of a strategic partnership via Lost Soldier and reflects his history of growing assets and companies — not involvement in criminal legal cases tied to fraud or racketeering.

data.author: Early_Bird
data.content: Paygrove, have you heard of ChatGPT? a very useful tool this day and age and will answer all the questions you're posting on here. Its good that you're probing though... going deeper in your research than most punters that just chase noise Alright, oil & gas resources 101—this is a good question and one a lot of people mix up. ### What are **2C Contingent Resources**? **2C** is the *best estimate* (or “most likely”) volume within **Contingent Resources** under the PRMS (Petroleum Resources Management System). Contingent Resources are: * **Discovered** hydrocarbons (there’s been a well, test, or solid evidence) * **Not yet commercial** because of *contingencies* like: * No development plan yet * Economics not approved * Regulatory or fiscal uncertainty * Missing infrastructure * Pending technology or market access Think of **2C** as: > “We know the hydrocarbons are there, and this is our most realistic volume — we just haven’t cleared all the business or technical hurdles yet.” --- ### What are **Prospective Resources**? Prospective Resources are: * **Undiscovered** * Based on geological interpretation, seismic, and analogs * Dependent on: * A future discovery * Development feasibility * Commercial approval In plain terms: > “We *think* hydrocarbons might be there, but we haven’t drilled and proven it.” They’re typically expressed with: * **Low / Best / High estimates** * **Chance of Discovery (Pg)** --- ### Why **2C is better than Prospective** “Better” here means **lower risk and higher confidence**. | Aspect              | 2C Contingent            | Prospective             | | ------------------- | ------------------------ | ----------------------- | | Discovery status    | ✅ Discovered             | ❌ Undiscovered          | | Geological risk     | Low                      | High                    | | Data quality        | Wells + tests + seismic  | Mostly seismic + models | | Key risk            | Commercial / development | Geological + commercial | | Closer to reserves? | ✅ Yes                    | ❌ Much earlier          | | Typical value       | Higher                   | Lower                   | So: * **2C has already cleared geological risk** * **Prospective still has to prove hydrocarbons even exist** That’s why investors, lenders, and partners usually: * Discount **Prospective Resources heavily** * Take **2C much more seriously**, especially if contingencies are clear and solvable --- ### Simple analogy * **Prospective**: *“There might be gold in that mountain.”* * **2C Contingent**: *“We’ve found gold, measured it, but we haven’t built the mine yet.”*
